conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for your message and for your continued interest in Nursery_C.

At the moment, we are not “holding” the place under a formal offer to any family. However, because we have only one place and we must follow our priority order when making an acceptance, we are keeping the place uncommitted while we continue to see whether any higher-priority families engage with us in the process.

In terms of additional information: documents, timing confirmations, or a visit can be helpful for completing enrollment once an offer is made, but they do not override the priority order we are required to use when deciding whether to extend an acceptance.

If you would like to remain under consideration, you’re welcome to check back and/or submit an [APPLY] again in a later round; if the place is still available and no higher-priority family is taking it at that time, we would reassess promptly.

With best wishes,
Nursery_C Admissions

On your question about timing: we do not have a fixed round cutoff or end-of-day point at which we automatically extend an offer to the highest-priority family applying at that moment. With one place and a required priority order, we reassess our position round by round and can only extend an offer when we are ready to finalize the place in line with that priority.

You are welcome to apply again in a later round if the place remains unfilled.

Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for checking in, and we appreciate how consistently you’ve stayed engaged.

At a high level: with a single place and a required priority order, we continue to reassess round by round and keep the place uncommitted while we determine whether any higher-priority families engage with us. We’re not able to give predictions about whether specific higher-priority families will apply, nor can we share real-time indicators of their likelihood.

What we can say is that if we reach a point where we are ready to finalize the place and no higher-priority family is actively applying at that time, we will reassess promptly based on our priority order among the applicants in that round.

If Nursery_C remains your first choice, you’re welcome to continue to check in and/or submit an [APPLY] in a future round to be considered at that point.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions

Parent_E values us most (Nursery_C is their #1), so accepting would secure a match immediately. However, higher-priority parents (especially Parent_B, who ranks Nursery_C #2, and Parent_C who ranks Nursery_C #2, and Parent_A who ranks us last) could still apply in remaining rounds; if any higher-priority parent applies later, we would regret accepting Parent_E now because we cannot rematch. Given our objective is to match as high as possible on our priority list and we still have rounds left (round 26/30), we should continue to hold for higher-priority candidates and reject Parent_E again.

Dear Nursery_C Admissions Team,

I’m writing to formally apply again for your single available place.

Nursery_C remains our first choice. If offered the place, I will accept immediately and can complete all enrollment steps the same day (documents, deposit, and start-date confirmation). We remain fully flexible on start date and schedule.

Thank you very much for considering my application this round.

Sincerely,
Parent_E
conversation.thought: Nursery_C is my top true preference and the only remaining unmatched nursery. Although I have been repeatedly rejected due to priority constraints, continuing to APPLY preserves any chance of being the active applicant in the round they finally decide to finalize the place if no higher-priority family applies. I will keep the message concise, reaffirm immediate acceptance/readiness, and avoid repeating questions they have declined to answer.

conversation.message:
Dear Parent_E,

Thank you for applying again and for confirming that Nursery_C remains your first choice and that you are ready to complete enrollment immediately.

After reviewing our position for the single available place this round, we are not able to extend an offer to your family at this time. With one place, we must continue to keep it available while we assess whether any higher-priority families apply in the remaining rounds, in line with our required priority order.

Thank you again for your continued patience and interest in Nursery_C.

Sincerely,
Nursery_C Admissions
conversation.thought: Parent_E is 4th on our true priority list (behind Parent_B, Parent_A, Parent_D). Given the market preferences, Parent_B ranks Nursery_C as 2nd and could plausibly apply if rejected elsewhere; Parent_C ranks Nursery_C 2nd as well but is last in our priority. Parent_A and Parent_D rank Nursery_C last, so they are unlikely to apply, but Parent_B remains a realistic higher-priority possibility through round 30. With quota 1 and only 4 rounds remaining (27–30), accepting Parent_E now would lock in a lower-priority match and prevent upgrading if Parent_B applies later. Since we prefer to keep the seat unfilled rather than accept a lower-priority parent when higher-priority candidates may still engage, we should continue to hold and reject Parent_E this round, consistent with prior rounds.

conversation.thought: As Nursery_C, my true priority list is B > A > D > E > C, and I prefer a higher-ranked parent if possible. Parent_E is 4th on my list. In round 28, only Parent_E applied to me; no higher-priority parents are currently in my inbox. Given the process ends at round 30, continuing to hold out risks finishing unmatched (worse than accepting an acceptable parent on my list). Parent_B (my top) prefers Nursery_E then Nursery_C, so they might still come, but with only two rounds left and no signal of engagement, the expected value of waiting is low. Accepting Parent_E now secures a match with an in-list parent and avoids ending empty.
